sect1.title: Conclusion
sect1.para: Mastering the clinical interview requires interpersonal and technical skills. An effective interviewer finds a synergy between cultivating a collaborative, empathetic therapeutic relationship and gathering information. To do this, empathy and rapport are foundational to a safe, trusting environment for clients to divulge personal information. Cultural humility and cultural empathy are critical to building rapport and trust. In terms of methods to collect personal information, unstructured, semi-structured, and structured interviews are used to assess symptoms, inform diagnosis, and case conceptualization. Choosing one of these strategies can be a complex decision and can depend on the purpose of the interview, the setting in which the interview will take place, and the amount of time available to administer the interview. Each type of interview has potential benefits and drawbacks to consider. As reviewed, structured interviews maximize validity and reliability, while unstructured interviews encourage open, free communication, rich data collection, and rapport-building.

The evolution of the clinical interview will continue to occur in tandem with innovation and advancement in psychology. For example, additional research is necessary to learn more about the degree of acceptability and validity of different types of interviews when administered across a diverse multicultural population. Several of the semi-structured and structured interviews described earlier are consistent with the diagnostic taxonomy of the DSM-5; however, the DSM is not the only classification system used in the field of psychology. Standardized interviews, such as the ones described in this chapter, will continue to be revised in concurrence with our understanding and conceptualization of mental health disorders. Although artificial intelligence continues to evolve in domains of information aggregation and use, clinical interviewing remains a fundamental skillset based in a human-to-human connection. As psychology continues to progress, the clinical interview continues to be a central and foundational practice.
